DataElement.preferredName: Posterior Pharynx Kaposi Sarcoma Present Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indicator of whether or not Kaposi Sarcoma oral lesions are present in the posterior pharynx.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Denoting the back surface of the body; at or near the hind end in quadrupeds or toward the spine in primates._A hollow tube that starts posterior to the mouth and nasal cavity and ends superior to the trachea and esophagus._A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin; however it may also occur internally. It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS)._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Denoting the back surface of the body; at or near the hind end in quadrupeds or toward the spine in primates.:The hollow tube inside the neck that starts behind the nose and ends at the top of the trachea (windpipe) and esophagus (the tube that goes to the stomach). The pharynx is about 5 inches long, depending on body size.:A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin; however it may also occur internally. It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Concepts.definition: Denoting the back surface of the body; at or near the hind end in quadrupeds or toward the spine in primates.
A hollow tube that starts posterior to the mouth and nasal cavity and ends superior to the trachea and esophagus.

A malignant neoplasm characterized by a vascular proliferation which usually contains blunt endothelial cells. Erythrocyte extravasation and hemosiderin deposition are frequently present. The most frequent site of involvement is the skin; however it may also occur internally. It generally develops in people with compromised immune systems including those with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS).

Property.preferredDefinition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
